posts.com:
Just made my first espresso with my Christmas present to myself, a Wacaco Picopresso and a Kingrinder K4. For a first attempt from someone who doesn't know dick about espresso making, the result was actually quite nice. About as good as the average shot you'd get at a Starbucks; which I know to the aficionado might not be saying much, but for a novice like me, that was kind of the baseline of quality. Now comes the fun part, the next ten shots of espresso where I figure out the right grind setting, the right dosage amount, the right water ratio, the right extraction time, etc.

Incidentally, the K4 on Amazon US is relatively inexpensive. I don't remember if it's a clone of the 1Zpresso JX, JX-Pro, or J-Max, but it's currently sitting at $88 USD, about half the cost of a JX-Pro, and $11 cheaper than the Q2, which is the "entry level" 1Z model. I don't know if it's on sale, or if that's the new price, but it's way cheaper than the various guides and reviews online would suggest.
https://www.amazon.com/KINGrinder-Adjustable-Settings-Aeropress-Consistency/dp/B09WH4B91L

>>18755425
I know it'll sound like shilling, but I
just got a K4 as I mentioned, >>18755344 and immediately loved it. The results I got on the very first "test shot," which I was expecting to throw out so I can fine tune the variables, was so good that I didn't bother making a second one. The recommended setting that Kingrinder gives for espresso is 60 clicks, which was too fine, so I'd recommend doing maybe 58 or 62, whichever direction is coarser. The one gripe I do have with the K4, which isn't a dealbreaker, is that the zero point on the grinder out of the box is bullshit. There's a big 0 printed on the turning mechanism, but the actual zero point of the burrs is either plus or minus 5, depending on whether you go all the way open or all the way closed.

I've gone though over a dozen different grinders and coffee machines, and dozens of hipster specialty coffees... but always default back to 1kg bags of lavazza from walmart and my krups blade grinder in an aeropress using a scale.

Fuck specialty coffees, fuck expensive grinders, fuck coffee makers and espresso machines. I just want smooth, consistent, and strong coffee with zero acidity or bitterness that I can brew while my frying pan is heating up in the morning. It takes up minimal counter space, just a tiny corner beside my toaster and the only cleanup is dumping grounds and filter directly into the trash and a rinse.

Its just so consistent, so good at being perfectly average: it's the most boringly average cup of coffee I can make in 3 minutes directly in my cup.

Those cups are fine but i really strongly suggest getting a porcelain gaiwan, clay changes the flavor of tea and is this whole other autistic thing and cheap slipcast clay is the opposite of the avoiding weird chemicals thing you are going for. Buying gaiwans on amazon is kind of annoying because they don't list the sizes correctly most of the time. You want one with a usable capacity of 100-150 ml, sometimes they list the total capacity, not all of which is usable, sometimes they list a number which is unrelated to the actual capacity. Yunnansoucring.us and purple cloud tea hous both have cheap teaware and more accurate measuments. Or just get something off of aliexpress

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18755289
No seriously avoid that fake yixing stuff its 100% tainted or wont include yixing clay in the first place, ive never seen anyone have an issue with cheap porcelain but get a glazed one if you're in doubt
real yixing clay is really hard so it cannot be made using standard methods like slipcasting or with a jolly-jigger machine so it has to be slab built either by hand or with a half-handmade mold where after using the mold the spout and handle still have to be put on by hand. With the fake stuff they add things to the yixing clay or most likely its just some random clay where they try to make it look more like yixing and to make it usable with cheaper production methods.

It's difficult to say what the "best" food pairing is, as it really depends on personal preference. However, some other classic food pairings that may be considered by some to be just as good as pizza and beer include:

Burgers and fries with a cold glass of milk
Grilled cheese sandwich with tomato soup
Spaghetti and meatballs with a glass of red wine
Sushi and sake
BBQ ribs and a cold craft beer
Lobster and butter with a bottle of white wine
Tacos and margaritas
Steak and potatoes with a Cabernet Sauvignon
Fried chicken and coleslaw with a sweet tea
Bangers and mash with a pint of ale
Again, these are just a few examples, and there are countless other great food and drink pairings to enjoy.

>>18755123
Yes, salt does have a significant effect on the texture of baked goods. In dough, salt helps to strengthen the gluten network, which gives structure and support to the finished product. It also helps to inhibit the action of enzymes that can break down the gluten, which can lead to a more tender crumb. In addition to these structural roles, salt also helps to balance and enhance the flavor of the dough or baked goods.

However, it's important to note that the amount of salt used in dough should be carefully balanced, as too much salt can lead to a overly dense or heavy finished product. It is generally recommended to use only a small amount of salt in dough, typically around 1-2% of the weight of the flour.

posts.sub: Weird food combos you like but most people haven't tried
posts.com:
For me here are the ones that I tried on another person's suggestion so may be more of a known thing:
>Peanut Butter and Pickle Sandwich
Surprisingly ok. I think I've eaten it 3 times in my life and all three times it was a late night act of desperation that I just so happened to have bread but no normal food toppings. Fortunately peanut butter and pickles tend to last a long time even after opening the jar. The acidity and juicyness of the pickles compliments the peanut butter better than possibly anything else can.

>Meatballs with a sauce primarily made out of grape jelly
Sort of teriyaki beef jerky kind of sweetness flavor. Reminded me of Blues Hog BBQ sauce which has a fuck ton of sugar in it. I wouldn't have it again because I tend to prefer all savory with no sweetness but I can see how a lot of people would like this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18753154
Now for the combos that I have personally come up with myself and tried out spontaneously that I turned out to like, so more likely others haven't tried:
>Potato chips and cottage cheese
Use the cottage cheese like a dip that you scoop with the potato chip. It's such a perfect combination that as far as I know am the only person that does this.
To add to this, if you have a particular hot sauce that has great flavor but is hot as fuck to the point where you can't enjoy it, try lacing the cottage cheese up with it first. It will cut the hotness way down and allow you to enjoy the flavor.

>50/50 mayo/sour cream as a dip for fries
If you are someone that eats fries with ranch dressing, try this instead. It has a much fresher taste while satisfying the same kind of craving and gives you the feeling like you just ate a baked potato with sour cream. I have been doing this since I was like 8 years old, no idea where I got the idea but my parents say it was all me, no one else in my family does it and they remember when I first concocted the mixture. I know the Dutch eat fries with straight up mayo but this mix is superior IMO.

>Mac and cheese made with (a lot) of vinegar
I originally started putting a bit of vinegar in my mac noodles to keep them from sticking together too much after boiling. One day I accidentally put way more than normal in, and it turned out to be really fucking good in the way that salt/vinegar chips are good. I'm sure this one won't be for everybody but if you are a vinegar fiend like myself you will like this shit. I like to use apple cider vinegar.

I would really like to hear about other stuff like this if anyone has any.

Pizza is a highly subjective food, and different people have different tastes and preferences. Some people may prefer the thin, crisp crust and simple toppings of New York-style pizza, while others may prefer the thicker, softer crust and more complex toppings of Detroit-style pizza. There is no one "best" style of pizza - it's all a matter of personal taste. That being said, it's perfectly okay to have your own opinions and preferences when it comes to food. If you think Detroit-style pizza is the best, then that's your opinion and it's perfectly valid.

>>18754238
It's true that different regions of the world have their own unique styles of pizza, and many people may not have had the opportunity to try all of them. Pizza is a global food, and there are many different variations to be found around the world, each with its own unique characteristics and flavors. The Okanagan region of British Columbia is known for its fresh, locally sourced ingredients, and it's possible that wood-fired pizza made with these ingredients could be delicious. It's always interesting to try new foods and discover new flavors and culinary traditions from different parts of the world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Bought some caviar for New Years. How do I serve/eat it? I have blinis—should I have something else with it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18755886
>diced shallot
>capers
>mayonnaise
>lemon

those are some traditional accoutrement for caviar. generally speaking, you want a neutral bread to spread it on like blinis, unsalted crackers, or white toast if all else fails. And then you want to add things that will accent but not overpower the caviar's natural flavors. Hence, mayonnaise can give you some unctuousness while staying neutral flavor-wise, shallots will give some texture and pungency while staying relatively mild in flavor, capers will bring some briny & salty enhancement, and lemon will add bright contrast without eclipsing the salty umami flavors of the caviar. Good luck, and please kill yourself.

It is true that the popularity of veganism has increased in recent years, and there are now more vegan options available in supermarkets and restaurants. However, this does not mean that vegetarianism has been completely forgotten or replaced. Many people still choose to follow a vegetarian diet for a variety of reasons, including health, environmental concerns, and animal welfare.

There are still a wide variety of vegetarian options available in supermarkets, including dairy products, eggs, and plant-based alternatives to meat and other animal products. It is also possible to find vegetarian options at many restaurants, although the availability of these options may vary.

In general, it is important to remember that everyone has different dietary needs and preferences, and it is important to find a way of eating that works for you. Whether you choose to follow a vegetarian or vegan diet, or something else entirely, it is important to make sure you are getting all the nutrients your body needs to stay healthy.

Cider is a type of beverage made from the fermented juice of apples. In the United States, cider is often used to refer specifically to a type of sweet, unfiltered apple juice that is made from crushed apples and is often consumed as a non-alcoholic beverage. The term "cider" is also sometimes used to refer to a type of alcoholic beverage made from fermented apple juice, which is similar to but stronger than regular cider. This type of cider is often referred to as "hard cider" to distinguish it from non-alcoholic cider. In other parts of the world, the term "cider" is more commonly used to refer to alcoholic cider, while non-alcoholic apple juice is referred to as simply "apple juice."

Have only really explored the BC scene as I live here, what are your highlights from the other provinces?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18748475
Trans Canada Brewing in Winnipeg
Rebellion Brewing in Regina
Haven't been to any breweries in Ontario that really blew me away but most of them are alright. Best I've been to was probably Tooth and Nail Brewing in Ottawa. The waitress also wasn't wearing a bra and there was a nice bakery across the road.
In Quebec, Frontibus and Naufrager in Gaspesie both make some great beers. Fin du Monde also comes in tallboys in Quebec and you can buy them for 4$ at grocery stores. Probably my favourite beer province not so much for going to breweries but almost all the beer is good and you can buy it anywhere.
Only been to one brewery in New Brunswick, Four Rivers in Bathurst. It was okay but nothing special, which is kind of the impression I've gotten of most NB beers.
Only been to PEI Brewing on PEI. Nothing special.
In Nova Scotia, the best brewery I went to was 2 Crows in Halifax, but I think most of the beer I had from Halifax breweries was pretty good. Schoolhouse Brewery in Windsor was pretty good too.
All the breweries I've visited in Alberta have been kind of eh, but I'm sure there's a good one out there. I had a rye beer from Medicine Hat Brewing which was alright.
In the Yukon, Winterlong is probably the most consistently good but Woodcutters Blanket has made some okay beers and Polarity does some good ones too. Yukon Brewing has been on a downward trend in quality the last three years.
Haven't had any beer from NWT, Nunavut or Newfoundland.
Another of my favourite breweries in BC is Backroads Brewing in Nelson. Also like Category 12 in Saanichton and Driftwood in Victoria (pic related is one of my all time favourite beers).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18748475
>>18748507
Pile'O'Bones (SK), Unibroue (QC), Fuggles & Warlock (BC), and Grizzly Paw (AB) are my favorite Canadian breweries.

I'm pretty much only familiar with SK/AB/BC/YT beer as I've lived in all four locations for a time. I find Rebellion mediocre for SK breweries. Pile'O'Bones, Nokomis, 9 Mile, Malty National, and Bushwakker are all better. I think I have tried every brewery in SK, and those are the best ones and they are very good. For a fairly small province SK has remarkably good food and drink.

YT is small enough that I tried everything and nothing was memorable.

AB I haven't delved into that hard. Everything from Calgary was bad. Grizzly Paw from Canmore is very good, especially on tap. Jasper Brewing I have only had on tap and it was consistently good, but nothing stellar.

The BC beer scene is far more diverse than SK but overwhelmingly disappointing. I've had Dageraad, Strange Fellows, Tailout, Phillips, Hoyne, Lighthouse, Townsite, Persephone, Whistler Brewing, Fuggles & Warlock, Torchlight, Nelson Brewing, Granville Island, Over Time, Grist & Mash, Fernie Brewing, Arrowhead, Whitetooth, Mt. Begbie, Field House, and a bunch of others that I can't even remember. Most of these I have had beer on tap at the breweries themselves.

Fuggles&Warlock and Dageraad are best overall BC breweries.
Field House has one standout blackberry/blueberry sour.
Fernie Brewing has one standout seasonal pumpkin ale.
Whistler has one standout seasonal winter dunkel (sweet orange&spice dessert beer).
Granville Island has a night light summer raspberry ale.
The rest are forgettable and can't even do a good basic brown, amber, etc.

>>18746943
County of origin, type of sugar cane byproduct used (cane juice, sugar, molasses, other), still used (pot, column, both) and aging are the most important factors. Good luck finding most of that out with your average rum. Agricole is a legal term and usually means cane juice and a vegetal and herbal flavor. Age means little because it's so hot in the tropics and some of the barrel houses are at high altitude.

posts.com:
>>18703613
I don't like:

1) Processed cheese. Anyone who puts processsed cheese on a burger should get a firing squad. Unless you're a wagie at a fast food place, there are no excuses for doing this shit, ever.

2) Fried eggs. The sulfur taste of the yolk and the texture of the eggs clashes with the rest. If you made a thin omelette and folded it and put it on the burger that could work for a breakfast burger, but that's about the only reason I can think of.

3) Olives, marinated artichokes or pickled peppers: They're fucking great, especially in sandwiches, but they're too wet and don't pair well with other ingredients.

4) Any kind of weird shit mixed into the ground beef used to make the burger patties. The beef should contain only beef, and perhaps salt. MAYBE you can add black pepper. MAYBE. If the beef is getting old then crust it in garlic powder to mask the taste a bit, but that's only if the beef is on the edge of inedible. Don't drown it in a ton of butter or oil. Put the patties in a little oil to start with, but let them cook in their own fat.

5) Non-western spices/ingredients. Anyone who adds weird goop like gookchang should be given a free helicopter ride.

6) Excessive grease or sauce. I don't like a slimy burger, fuck off with that shit.

7) Fake meat. I don't need to say anything else.
A burger can contain any kind of meat, but it should have meat. Not sure what to call Portobello burgers.

8) Foods which are generally incompatible with the structure of a burger, or which don't pair with burgers well. Overly sweet things, for example. So, no donuts or strudels.

I can't think of anything else, is that a good list?

>ordering no salt fries at mcdicks to "force them to make a fresh batch"
I hate this "lifehack" with an undying fucking passion. I am convinced people doing this is 100% to blame for fast food restaurants never salting their fries appropriately any more. Instead of getting nice salty fries with salt melted right into the oil as it dries on the surface of the fries you get bland saltless fries that you have to try to add salt to when they're already dry and cool, it doesn't taste the same. On the plus side, this phenomenon has reduced my consumption of fast food in general, but I wish I could still get a nice well-salted order of fries now and again and I blame those retarded lifehack fucks for permanently ruining it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I started making burgers at home I realised how little you actually need to make a good burger.
Lots of toppings just overcrowds a burger, makes it sloppy and unstable, you honestly just need 1 strongly flavoured topping.
My top is:
- jalapenos
- pickles (salt ones not vinegar)
- olives (green)
- NO KETCHUP, literally anything is better, I usually like weird shit like remoulade, but even mayo or a generic burger sauce is better than ketchup.
I don't even use cheese sometimes because i can't even taste it in the burger. Unless i use something strong. Irish cheddar actually worked well.
I should try to make the OG too, mustard, onions and meat. That's it. Should be tasty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Best way to prepare octopus?
And what's a good size for a serving of 2-3 portions? Any pointers for picking out fresh ones?

I was thinking simple olive oil, salt, a spritz of lemon. Maybe a dip.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are many different ways to prepare octopus, but here is a simple recipe that yields tender and flavorful results:

Ingredients:

1 medium octopus (about 1.5-2 pounds)
2 tablespoons olive oil
1 teaspoon salt
Freshly squeezed lemon juice (optional)
Instructions:

Rinse the octopus under cold water and pat dry with paper towels.
Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Carefully add the octopus to the pot and cook for 45 minutes to 1 hour, or until the octopus is tender.
Remove the octopus from the pot and let it cool until it is easy to handle. Cut off the head and discard it, then cut the tentacles into bite-sized pieces.
Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the octopus pieces and cook for 2-3 minutes, or until they are lightly browned.
Season the octopus with salt and a squeeze of lemon juice, if desired. Serve hot.
As for serving size, a medium octopus (about 1.5-2 pounds) should be enough to serve 2-3 portions.

When selecting fresh octopus, look for ones that are firm to the touch and have a mild, sweet smell. Avoid octopuses that are slimy or have a strong, fishy smell. It is also a good idea to check the expiration date and choose the freshest octopus available. If you are not comfortable handling live octopuses, you can also find frozen or pre-cooked octopus at many seafood markets and specialty stores.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ez ass meal for two with leftover pasta cooking for more? buy more sausage

1 28oz can of whole tomatoes (san marzano style preferred) -1.19
1 lb of linguine -89 cents
5 tablespoons of butter - 20 cents worth?
1 yellow onion -79 cents
2 one dollar hot Italian sausages from the deli

should be close to 5 dollars

Combine the tomatoes, butter and onion(only cut in half) in a pan and cook for 45 mins breaking the tomatoes down with a spatula. No less no more time. Salt and pepper to taste. Start boiling pasta water 5 mins before your 45 min timer is up.
Once done remove the sauce and remove the onion from the sauce. Wipe out the pan add in the sausage and brown them up cook for 12-14 mins or so. While they are cooking cook your pasta for 10 mins or until al dente.

Serve the sauce over the pasta and slice up the sausage and place it on the side of the pasta. Place 2-3 of the onion pieces on the side of the pasta as well they should be well cooked and translucent. Grate some parmesan over the pasta if you have some. Can serve with a buttered french bread chunk as well.

Pic related and trust me its one of the best sauces you can make. Look up Marcella Hazan tomato sauce.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18752666
>Also is it true that in Burgerland you can only get sushi from sit down resturaunts and grocery stores? In Australia ‘fast food’ sushi is everywhere, you just pick what you want from the display and walk off.
(Checked.) That sounds nice. I think it's fair to say that sit-down restaurants and supermarkets are the norm, along with sometimes convenience stores (like at petrol stations). In large urban areas you might (MIGHT) find a Japanese food truck to sushi to-go.


But there is a special category of restaurants worth mentioning: all-you-can-eat Asian buffets. Some are "Chinese", some are "hibachi", they all have a wide selection "American Chinese" sloppa alongside normal American buffet fare... but often also sushi and even sashimi. Of course it's not the same as a proper Japanese restaurant, and the selection is limited. (Lots of California rolls, salmon, tuna, imitation crab. Not so much eel.) But it's usually a little fresher than than supermarket sushi, and you can eat 40 pieces if you're so inclined for like $10-15.

(To be fair, pic related is from an article called "Why You Shouldn't Touch the Sushi at All-You-Can-Eat Buffets", citing concerns about temperature control. But if you visit during peak hours, it's usually not sitting around for very long.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18752376
>anyone who makes sushi knows a safe way to deal with raw fish?

I've been eating raw fish at home for about 4 years now. there are 2 main risks with raw fish:

>parasites
do your research to learn which fish carry the highest risk, but in general, anything that spends time in fresh water can have parasites, while fish that live exclusively in saltwater rarely have parasites. So if you want to eat raw salmon, it's best to freeze it to a temperature and for a time that will kill any parasites. Most places selling "sashimi grade" salmon use that term to indicate it's been frozen properly to eliminate any parasites. Again, do your research here, because freezing to eliminate parasites works the same as pasteurization: you need to hit a target temperature for a set amount of time. Your home freezer may not get cold enough to practically do this.

>salmonella
Salmonella lives in the guts of fish. So when the fish is gutted, if the knife that opens the belly pierces the guts AND pierces the meat, then the meat is contaminated. The only protection you have is to trust your source of fish not to contaminate their product. If you don't trust them, your options are either to cook the fish (this kills the salmonella) or catch your own damn fish and process it yourself. Plenty of reputable places online will ship sashimi-grade, salmonella-free fish to your door. So if you don't trust anyone local, try Fulton, Riviera, or somewhere else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I finally quit after 12 years of nicotine use and I feel completely fine. It was only hell for about a week, and then there were 2 more weeks of constantly thinking about nicotine and having to be sad that I couldn't have anymore. But now it's been a month and I'm completely over it, no more withdrawal symptoms, no more cravings, just feel 100% fine and normal. Except I don't need to keep consuming nicotine in order to be comfortable. I basically can just be comfortable indefinitely. It feels like there's a magical nicotine patch inserted inside my skin and it never runs out, so it just keeps feeding me pleasure and keeping me feeling content. I had no idea I could be like this. It's really awesome.

I always thought that if I quit, my life would basically be hell forever, since I'd always have to keep missing nicotine every day for the rest of my life. I thought it would be like having a wife tragically killed in a car accident and then you always miss her forever. I thought that even though the physical withdrawal could obviously go away, and chemically my brain would go back to normal, I'd never be able to forget the knowledge of how much I love smoking and dipping. I thought since I ate the forbidden fruit of knowledge, I was doomed to nicotine slavery forever.

I just can't express to you guys how fucking crazy it is that the feeling of missing cigarettes and feeling down and "lonely" about quitting, it literally just went away in under a month. I can't believe it was that fucking easy all along, and I just never stuck it out long enough to find this out sooner. I have been an addict for 12 fucking years and wishing I could stop for most of that time. And all along I literally could.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18752727
I like gamjajorim, it's a potato side dish that is sweet and savory.

Chicken-mu is a refreshing alternative to kimchi. It's just picked radish, usually eaten alongside fried chicken hence the name.

Chamchi-jeon is tuna pancakes. Very easy to make, savory too. I like to eat this with a dip made with a ratio of 2 tbsp soy sauce, 2 tsp brown sugar, 2 tsp sesame oil, 2 tsp chili powder, 1 minced garlic, and 1 tbsp hot water.

There's also japchae, and most foreigners typically like it. Not my personal favorite though because it's oily.

>t. Korean

Remember that thread about chocolate containing high levels of heavy metal contamination awhile ago?
https://www.reuters.com/legal/hershey-sued-over-chocolate-containing-heavy-metals-2022-12-29/
>NEW YORK, Dec 29 (Reuters) - Hershey Co (HSY.N) has been sued by a consumer who accused the company of selling dark chocolate that contains harmful levels of lead and cadmium. In a proposed class action filed on Wednesday, Christopher Lazazzaro said he would not have bought or would have paid less for Hershey's Special Dark Mildly Sweet Chocolate, Lily's Extra Dark Chocolate 70% Cocoa and Lily's Extreme Dark Chocolate 85% Cocoa had Hershey disclosed their metals content.

>Hershey did not immediately respond on Thursday to requests for comment on the lawsuit, which was filed in the federal court in Central Islip, New York. Lazazzaro, a resident of Nassau County, New York, sued two weeks after Consumer Reports unveiled the results of scientific testing of 28 dark chocolate bars for lead and cadmium. Hershey's Special Dark bar and Lily's 70% bar were high in lead, and Lily's 85% bar was high in lead and cadmium, the magazine said. Lazazzaro said reasonable consumers would be turned off by such levels because they pose a "serious health risk," and that consumers rely on Hershey to be truthful about ingredients in its products.

>The lawsuit seeks at least $5 million of damages, including at least $500 per transaction under New York law. Hershey bought Lily's for $425 million in June 2021. The case is Lazazzaro v Hershey Co, U.S. District Court, Eastern District of New York, No. 22-07923.

There's a CR petition you can sign to prod for supply chain reform:
https://action.consumerreports.org/20221215_heavymetalschocolate_cro
https://www.consumerreports.org/health/food-safety/lead-and-cadmium-in-dark-chocolate-a8480295550/
But if a class action is what it takes to compel action then so be it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's understandable to feel bad about not making healthy choices with your diet. It can be difficult to change long-standing habits, but it's important to remember that it's never too late to make a change. Here are a few tips that might help you feel better about your diet and make positive changes:

Start small: Rather than trying to overhaul your entire diet at once, start by making small, manageable changes. For example, try replacing one serving of soda or fast food with a piece of fruit or a healthier snack each day.

Focus on progress, not perfection: It's okay to indulge in unhealthy foods occasionally. What's important is to try to make healthier choices most of the time and focus on the progress you're making rather than trying to be perfect.

Plan ahead: Make a meal plan for the week and shop for healthy ingredients in advance. This can help you avoid the temptation to turn to unhealthy options when you're feeling hungry and don't have anything healthy on hand.

Don't beat yourself up: It's normal to have slip-ups, and it's important to be kind to yourself. If you do indulge in unhealthy foods, try to move on and make healthier choices at your next meal or snack.

Seek support: It can be helpful to enlist the support of friends, family, or a healthcare professional as you work to improve your diet. They can provide motivation and accountability as you make changes.

Remember, it's never too late to make positive changes to your diet and improve your overall health. It may take some time and effort, but the benefits are worth it.

nothing will change until you gain a good understanding of how many calories you should be consuming daily.
> start cooking for yourself, using raw ingredients
> start counting calories. yes, really. this means getting a kitchen scale and using it.

eventually you'll be to make good estimations of how much calories is in restaurant food (you can never be precise because restaurant food calorie content is very volatile) so that you can start re-introducing these foods back into your diet. you'll also notice that you don't crave it as much, and you have more self-control.

t. lost a lot of weight, have been lean for 15 years, have helped other people lose weight

can't say how good lidl's one is but i've had some damn good ajvars from jars.
as for making it at home, i don't know how much yugos do it but in bulgaria i'd say there's an 80/20 divide between getting it at the store vs. making it (in favor of getting it at the store). but again, we don't make ajvar here, we make lyutenitsa which is like ajvar but no eggplant and just tomato and peppers.

if it was bland for you, you can try the crumbled feta thing i guess. all the ajvars i've had were sweet, savory and smokey. but lidl sometimes does weird things with its regional products where they end up tasting like some weird amalgamation of each country's variant that isn't quite right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember middle school health class covering the food pyramid and how even as a child it felt sketchy at best. It's turned upside its head in so many ways. Even going by its min serving recommendations results in ~2100 calories a day. 2s milk (488g, 293cal) + 2s beef steak (170g, 428cal) + 3s mixed veg (30oz, 546cal) + 2s mixed fruit (324g, 194cal) + 6s grain (174g, 660cal) = 2121cal.
It's a categorical simplification that prioritizes ease of sorting over nutritional impact. Consider the analogy: An exercise pyramid that categorizes exercises by dumbbell, barbell, machine, no weights / body weight, etc.. It's stupid.

The truest statement on food health is, and always has been, "Eat a well balanced diet in moderation."
What makes a diet balanced? Depends more on your body than anything else. Sometimes your body needs more of something or doesn't need as much of something. That need, or lack thereof, could be short-, medium-, or long-term.
If your body is low on an essential nutrient (protein, vitamin, acids, etc..) then eat more foods that contribute to that, preferably while keeping your avg caloric intake approximately constant.
If you want to lose weight you don't even have to change the balance of your diet. Just literally eat less of the same diet. Although, if your protein intake would drop too much I recommend altering the diet a bit to prevent that. That and regular exercise will help reducing your muscle loss as you lose weight.

Also for fucks sake, stop thinking of nutrition as something that has to be met every day. It's a rolling average over days, if not weeks. You don't need some crazy diet that has all of your essentials every day. Some days you get more of this and less or none of that. It's all about averages over time. If you really need breakpoints, use 3d and 7d averages.
When I wanted to lose weight I lost an avg of 2 lbs/wk over 4 months even though some days I had ~2500cal because I kept my avg daily intake under my target ~1500cal.

>>18746663
Yes they are. Storing glucose as glycogen requires energy. While yes, the body is perfectly capable of producing glucose from sources that are not carbs it does not store that glucose as glycogen for future use. That glucose goes straight to use as the body requires glucose to operate. It makes no sense for our bodies to spend extra energy to produce excess glugoce that is then stored when you are already missing glucose and have to first inefficiently create glucose from other sources. And when we're talking glycogen stores it's obvious that I'm talking about the large scale stores. Sure small amounts might be stored as a buffer but adults have multiple kg of glycogen when their glycogen stores are full. It's also why everyone loses weight at first on keto even if they eat the same caloric intake. They expens their glycogen stores but can't replenish them. It's also why people gain weight when they stop keto while keeping the same caloric intake. Those same glycogen stores get filled as they eat carbs.

>>18752041
We are both Mexican living in Mexico eating mexican food.

I am from Sinaloa and she is from Guadalajara, so we are mixing some recipes.

Here is something that she discovered. There is a place in Culiacan named Palomar de los pobres. Just some grilled meat, nothing special, but the beans they serve are pretty good.
It has been a mystery trying to find the trick to make those. However, the first time she tried, she told me that they used “manteca de puerco”, pork lard. When we got back to Guadalajara, she made beans with pork lard and had the same fucking flavour.

Not the best pic but this is what I found.

It is funny because all the people from Culiacan tried to replicate those beans but my wife told me that it is a Guadalajara style.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: use a high-smoke-point oil (like peanut or vegetable oil), a starch-based coating (like cornstarch or potato starch), a wok for deep frying, the proper oil temperature, and a final stir-fry step to re-crisp the exterior and add flavor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They are almost always twice fried, like french fries. Your first fry you cook the chicken and set the batter. It should only be lightly colored. Then you let them cool completely before frying them again. This method just lets more moisture escape and preserves the crust for longer. This is how I make chili paneer and I use a cornstarch/flour batter. If my sauce isn't too liquid, they stay crispy for a long time.

The other thing Chinese restaurants do is leave their chicken pieces in a giant container of cornstarch for a long time, like all day. The liquid in the chicken is gradually released and more of the cornstarch sticks to it, making a thick crust. It also makes the little bits of chicken seem much bigger than they are. In general, keeping things crispy is about removing moisture.

Please share your results when you get happy with your recipe. Good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've had pretty good success using a more American method:

Chicken; cubed
Egg, beaten.
Mix.
Have Chicken/egg in 1 bowl and a bowl of flour.
Heat a CAST IRON skillet up with about 1/2 inch deep of Corn oil or Peanut oil. (350 degrees or so; or if it sizzles some flour if you sprinkle some in)
Then take each chicken and dip it in flour to cover, put in oil

leave it sizzle. Do not stir it around. Let the crust form wholly on one side first. Then flip each one. Maybe flip twice over; but the key is to not move them around too much.

It creates an amazing fucking crust that takes well for a Gen. Tso's sauce.

The main key things are oil type, pan type, not fiddling with your frying chicken like an idiot.

Here are a few ideas for recipes that you can make with tortillas and freeze for later:
Tortilla pizzas: Top a tortilla with tomato sauce, cheese, and your choice of toppings, then bake it in the oven until the cheese is melted and the tortilla is crispy.

Burritos: Fill a tortilla with beans, rice, cheese, and your choice of toppings, then roll it up and wrap it in foil. Freeze the burritos, then reheat them in the microwave or on the stove.

Tacos: Fill a tortilla with seasoned ground meat, cheese, and your choice of toppings (such as sautéed vegetables or black beans), then fold it in half and grill it until the cheese is melted. Freeze the tacos, then reheat them in the microwave or on the stove.

Tortilla chips: Cut the tortillas into wedges, then bake or fry them until they are crispy. Freeze the chips, then serve them with dips or use them to make nachos.

Main reason I use it is that it has 0.1 gram accuracy, my regular kitchen scale doesn't. When you're weighing out beans that's pretty useful since you're dealing with small quantities. >>>18746719
>K-cups do not have a degassing valve
Anon I see the issue with this, but I don't think that's what bothers me. Ground coffee will offgas bulk of it's co2 in first couple of days, and co2 is not what makes coffee fresh. Secondly I'm not expecting it to be fresh, just passable after being in a drawer for a year. Since the pods are nitrogen purged that should be a good way to store it.
>>>>>>>>>>>>
I did some experiments with leftover k-cups I had.
Coffee ones had 5-6 g of coffee, so in no way can it make more than a 6oz cup from a pod.
Tea had 2.5g of tea, which is more than a typical 2g teabag, should be able to make a cup.
Dicking around with machine, I found that the water comes out fairly cold and heats up mid way thru the brew.
The brew is also very fast, maybe a minute, which is not long enough to extract coffee or tea.
>>>>>>>>>>>>
As far as the instapod machine that can do both nespresso and k-cup.
Nespresso pod holds 5-6g of coffee also, and minimum size for the espresso on it is 2oz.
Which again for a decent espresso simulacrum it should make around 1oz of beverage.
The original machines make 40g shots, which is closer to what you'd want.
It also costs $200, and that's just not worth it for a half ass machine.
>>>>>>>>>>>>
This leaves me with either a nespresso, the original style not the weird spinny one, or maybe the illy pod machine and tea bags for tea.
>inb4 why pods
I really need this thing to be both long shelf life and normieproof.

Darker roasts have a more roasty, sometimes burned, flavor. The lighter the roast the more the flavor of the beans themselves comes through. Specialty roasters will roast light to medium usually, which you'd probably like. The actual taste will vary depending on where it's from.
I recommend hoff's video on buying coffee to give you some idea for what to look for

posts.com: Is it necessary to brine and or marinade it for many hours in order for the seasoning to penetrate or can I season just before cooking? Thanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18749204
chiggin's great because you can do either. I think it's best with a ~12hr brine, pat dry and then season/dry rub before roasting, but most of the time I bring a bird home and just season and roast and it's still pretty awesome.

The key is to NOT overcook and you should truss it. Alton Brown and Chef John have good truss advice. Get a good meat thermometer and know where to check the temp. Most of the time I end up way overcooking it and it's still awesome, and the one time I thought I way undercooked it actually ended up perfect.

Roasting a chicken better than the supermarket birds or Boston Market etc is easy but only once you really get it right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It is not accurate to say that shrimp are the cockroaches of the sea. Shrimp are a type of crustacean, closely related to lobsters and crabs, and are commonly eaten as a food source around the world. They do not have any close relationship to cockroaches, which are insects.

As for why shrimp taste good, it is likely due to their delicate, sweet flavor and tender texture. Different people may have different opinions about the taste of shrimp, but many people find them to be a delicious and enjoyable food.

It is not common for people to eat cockroaches, and it is not known what they would taste like if they were eaten. It is generally not considered safe or advisable to consume insects as food.

>>18753949
take the baking pill, cheap as fuck, just takes like 2 hours, fresh, delicious. even a retard like me can do it
1kg wheat flour
50g yeast
3.5dl water
spoon full of olive oil
some salt
olives
rosemary/thyme optional

1. dissolve yeast in luke warm water
2. add spoon of olive oil
3. add flour
mix, when it starts slipping from the walls of your bowl
4. fold in olives
5. cover in cloth and let rise for like 30-40 minutes
6. divide into however many loafs or buns you want
7. slice some groves in whatever pattern you want
8. drizzle oil on top, add salt and herbs
9. 230c for like 35-40 minutes, let rest for 10 minutes on a grate

>>18713841
I moved into a new house (new as in just built, not just new to me) early 2021. I did a low and slow cook of 2 racks of beef ribs in the oven, used a meat thermometer to ensure doneness. About 12 hours later came the worst stomach pain I’ve ever encountered. I could now smell traces of chemicals mixed in with my beef ribs and immediately threw the rest away.

I probably should have gone to the ER to get my stomach pumped but for every 2 hours of excruciating pain came 20 minutes of relief that tricked me into thinking it was finally over. All in all the first 24 hours were the worst but I was still on the mend 48 hours later.

When I put it together that the oven was clearly contaminated with something (I wouldn’t be surprised if it was even something like paint fumes trapped from the build process) I immediately put it on self clean mode and now I thoroughly wash every appliance or utensil prior to using it in a cook. It’s been almost 2 years and I’m afraid to try beef ribs again because I think the smell might cause my body to instinctively shut down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was very fat as a teenager. My cousin's kid was having a birthday party, and they were just chucking some stuff on the grill. Since there were a lot of people and they were all over the place, plates were placed out all around the house and the yard for people to grab food. Thus meant my parents couldn't really keep an eye on my consumption of food, like they usually do.

I downed 6 loaded hamburgers (as much cheese and bacon as patty), 5 bratwurst sandwiches, chips, a lot of soda, amd several slices of cake. Somehow I didn't actually feel too terrible in the moment, but just as we were leaving I started to feel queasy.

I had trouble falling asleep from the stomach ache. Eventually I did, but hours later (still in he dead of night) something inside me stirred violently and it awoke me. I had to rush naked to the bathroom and slammed my ass down on the toilet seat, where I proceeded to spew an ungodly amount of brown water from my asshole. This, combined with having consumed enough sodium earlier to have killed a horse, meant that as I sat there spewing forth a waterfall from my ass it felt like thick boiling poison was flowing through every one of my veins, a truly horrifying feeling. My stomach felt like someone was pumping it full of air to bursting point, and after that it happened.

Undigested chunks came flying out in an unholy cacophony. My body completely refused what I had crammed into it, and was just letting it all out. I spent HOURS on that toilet, not wanting to push because my asshole was incredibly sore and in tremendous pain, but needing to push because otherwise my stomach would act up and get stabbing pains. I unironically cried. After all the chunks had evacuated, I was left trying to push out a mostly clear, thick slime.

I washed my ass on the bidet (even the very gentle stream of water on my asshole stung by then) and I crawled back into bed teary eyed, feeling like what I can only asume violent anal rape by an elephant does, and passed out.

Man last night something fucked me up awful and I'm not sure what I'm experiencing. I had two cube steaks with some mushrooms, some cheese, a little jerkey for a snack later, then sipped on some bourbon before bed. I do this all the time, trying to trim down a little so I can pig out for Christmas. These are normal eating patterns for me when I'm cutting. Last night I woke up at about 2:30 with what felt like lava/battery acid erupting from my chest. It was the worst acid reflux I've ever experienced. Didnt habe to throw up or poop, just horrible acid. I was looking up symptoms and it seemed like GERD maybe. Can you get that any time?
Anyway, It was so painful I was tearing up. I went to my living room and sat in a recliner to try to keep my esophagus elevated. It helped a bit, but it just kept going. I tried to go throw up, but it was like 8f outside, so I hurried back in quick. I decides to eat some bread, and it actually did help calm my stomach down. I ended up eating a whole round of banana nut bread. If it helped, it helped, so I just fucking ate it.
Woke up this morning and it's still happening. Took some pepto, a couple tums, nothing is helping. Just horrible gas, burping, farting, and acid geysers coming from my stomach. I'm at work and it's absolute hell. I have no idea why this is happening, but I assume it's dietary, but I've never had anything like this happen before. It's so fucking uncomfortable. I'd rather just diarrhea and vomit instead, it's way easier to deal with.
